facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 401 of 1956

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 401 of 1956.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 8, 1956, of the Travancore-Cochin High Court at Ernakulam in I.T.R. No. 24 of 1954

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 8, 1956, of the Travancore-Cochin High Court at Ernakulam in I.T.R. No. 24 of 1954.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered by SARKAR J. on October 7, 1958

anchor.surface_text: 1958. October 7. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SARKAR J.-The appellant who was a Superintendent of Police

facts.text: Appellant was a Superintendent of Police in the service of the former Travancore State

anchor.surface_text: The appellant who was a Superintendent of Police in the service of the former Travancore State, retired sometime in 1940.

facts.text: Appellant retired sometime in 1940

anchor.surface_text: State, retired sometime in 1940. After retirement he was spending his time in studying Vedanta philosophy and expounding

facts.text: After retirement appellant studied Vedanta philosophy and expounded it to disciples

anchor.surface_text: After retirement he was spending his time in studying Vedanta philosophy and expounding the same to such persons as were keen on understanding it.

facts.text: One disciple was J. Levy of London, U.K.

anchor.surface_text: He soon gathered about him a number of disciples, one of whom was J. Levy of London, U.K.

facts.text: Levy received instructions in Vedanta from the appellant

anchor.surface_text: Levy along with others used to receive instructions in Vedanta from the appellant.

facts.text: Levy came to Travancore from England at regular intervals and stayed for a few months

anchor.surface_text: He used to companye to Travancore from England at regular intervals and stay there for a few months at a time

facts.text: Levy had an account in Lloyds Bank at Bombay

anchor.surface_text: Levy had an account in Lloyds Bank at Bombay. On December 13, 1941, Levy transferred the entire balance

facts.text: On December 13, 1941, Levy transferred Rs. 2,41,103-11-3 to appellant's account in Lloyds Bank, Bombay

anchor.surface_text: On December 13, 1941, Levy transferred the entire balance standing to his credit in this account amounting to Rs. 2,41,103-11-3, to the credit of an account

facts.text: Further sums deposited by Levy into appellant's account up to August 19, 1951, amounting to about Rs. 4,50,000/-

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, from time to time Levy put in further sums into the appellants aforesaid account in Lloyds Bank, Bombay. It appears that the payments so made up to August 19, 1951, amounted to about Rs. 4,50,000/-

facts.text: Appellant transferred moneys from Lloyds Bank Bombay to his account in Trivandrum

anchor.surface_text: From time to time the appellant got moneys transferred from his account at the Lloyds Bank, Bombay, to his account in a bank at Trivandrum in Travancore.

facts.text: Assessment years 1122, 1123, 1124 Malayalam era, corresponding to 17 Aug 1945-16 Aug 1946, 17 Aug 1946-16 Aug 1947, 17 Aug 1947-16 Aug 1948

anchor.surface_text: This appeal arises out of orders for assessment to income- tax passed against the appellant for the assessment years 1122, 1123 and 1124, all according to the Malayalam era. The respective accounting periods according to the Gregorian calendar were from August 17, 1945, to August 16, 1946, August 17, 1946, to August 16, 1947, and August 17, 1947, to August 16, 1948.

facts.text: Levy deposited Rs. 13,304/-, Rs. 29,948/-, Rs. 19,983/- in appellant's Bombay account during the three assessment periods

anchor.surface_text: It appears that during these periods Levy bad deposited in the appellants account at Lloyds Bank in Bombay the following respective sums Rs. 13,304/-, Rs. 29,948/- and Rs. 19,983/-

facts.text: Appellant obtained transfers of Rs. 81,200/-, Rs. 47,000/-, Rs. 37,251/- from Bombay to Trivandrum during the same periods

anchor.surface_text: During the same periods the appellant had obtained transfers of the following respective sums from his Bombay account to his Trivandrum account Rs. 81,200/-, Rs. 47,000/- and Rs. 37,251/-

facts.text: Income-tax Officer, Trivandrum, assessed appellant on the transferred amounts as foreign income brought into Travancore

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer, Trivandrum, assessed the appellant to tax on the latter amounts as foreign income, i.e., income arising in India, and brought into Travancore State in the relevant periods.

facts.text: Appellant appealed to Appellate Assistant Commissioner, who dismissed the appeal and confirmed ITO orders

anchor.surface_text: Tile appellant appealed from these assessment orders to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner who companysolidated them into one appeal. The Appellate Assistant Commissioner dismissed the appeal and companyfirmed the orders of the Income-tax Officer.

facts.text: Appeal to Appellate Tribunal failed

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then went up in appeal to the Appellate Tribunal but that appeal also failed.

facts.text: Tribunal referred two questions to High Court

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thereafter obtained an order from the Tribunal referring the following Questions to the High Court of Travancore-Cochin for decision Whether the aforesaid receipts from John H. Levy companystitute income taxable under the Travancore Income-tax Act, 1121 ?

facts.text: High Court answered first question affirmatively, second in favour of appellant

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the first question in the affirmative. It however answered the second question in favour of the appellant, holding that he was carrying on a vocation or occupation in that State

facts.text: Appellant appealed to Supreme Court by special leave against High Court's answer to first question

anchor.surface_text: The appellant has number companye up to this Court in appeal by special leave against the answer given -by the High Court to the first question.

facts.text: Appellant imparted Vedanta knowledge without condition of payment

anchor.surface_text: There is numberevidence to show, that the appellant had made it a companydition that he would impart such knowledge only to those who were prepared to pay for it.

issues.text: Whether the aforesaid receipts from John H. Levy constitute income taxable under the Travancore Income-tax Act, 1121?

anchor.surface_text: Whether the aforesaid receipts from John H. Levy constitute income taxable under the Travancore Income-tax Act, 1121 ?

issues.text: Whether there are materials for the Tribunal to hold that the deposits into the assessees bank account in Bombay by John H. Levy from 1941 as aforesaid represented income that accrued to the assessee outside Travancore State?

anchor.surface_text: and Whether there are materials for the Tribunal to hold that the deposits into the assessees bank account in Bombay by John H. Levy from 1941 as aforesaid represented income that accrued to the assessee outside Travancore State ?

anchor.surface_text: And secondly, if he was, can the amounts with which we are concerned, be said to be profits or gains of the vocation ? We agree with his view of the case and proceed to discuss these points.

issues.text: whether the appellant was carrying on a vocation

anchor.surface_text: The first question is, whether the appellant was carrying on a vocation. Under s. 10 of the Income-tax Act, 1922, tax is payable by an assessee in respect of the profit or gains of any profession or vocation carried on by him.

issues.text: whether the payments made by Levy were income received by the appellant from his vocation of teaching Vedanta

anchor.surface_text: Then the other point to be decided is, whether the payments made by Levy were income received by the appellant from his vocation of teaching Vedanta. A very large number of authorities, both Indian and English, have been pressed upon us in the course of the argument.

arguments.claim: The case involves two points: whether the appellant was carrying on a vocation and whether the amounts are profits or gains of that vocation

arguments.claim: Appellant teaching Vedanta constitutes carrying on a vocation under s.10 Income-tax Act

anchor.surface_text: The first question is, whether the appellant was carrying on a vocation. Under s. 10 of the Income-tax Act, 1922, tax is payable by an assessee in respect of the profit or gains of any profession or vocation carried on by him. The facts found are that the appellant was studying Vedanta philosophy himself and imparting the knowledge

arguments.claim: Teaching is plainly a vocation; teaching Vedanta is equally a vocation

anchor.surface_text: We find no difficulty in thinking that teaching is a vocation if not a, profession It is plainly so and it is not necessary to discuss the various meanings of the word. vocation for the purpose or to cite authorities to support this view. Nor do we find any reason why, if teaching is a vocation, teaching of Vedanta is not.

arguments.claim: No organisation or continuity required for vocation; single act suffices

anchor.surface_text: we have to point out that it is well-known that a single act may amount to the carrying on of a business or profession.

arguments.claim: Profit motive irrelevant to constituting business, profession or vocation

anchor.surface_text: Again, it is well-established that it is not the motive of the person doing an act which decides whether the act done by him is the carrying on of a business, profession or vocation. If any business, profession or vocation in fact produces an income, that is taxable income

arguments.court_reasoning: Cites Incorporated Council of Law Reporting (1888); followed ever since

arguments.claim: Stedeford v Beloe does not require profit motive

anchor.surface_text: The observation of Rowlatt, J., in Stedeford v. Beloe  2  to which we were referred by Mr. Sastri, that there could be no tax on pension granted to a retired  1   1888 3 Tax Cas. 105, 113.  2   1930  16 Tax Cas. 505. headmaster as there is no background of business in it , was clearly not intended to lay down that without a profit motive there could be no business, profession or vocation.

arguments.court_reasoning: Pension not from office held at grant time

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sastri contends that that may be so, but we have no right to follow the successive causes and as a result thereof link the gift with the teaching.

arguments.claim: Payments taxable if received by virtue of vocation, regardless of donor's motive

arguments.claim: Test: personal gift or remuneration by virtue of office/vocation

anchor.surface_text: It is well established that in cases of this kind the real question is, as Rowlatt J. put it in Reed v. Seymour  1 , But is it in the nature of a personal gift or is it a remuneration?, an observation which was quoted with approval by Viscount Cave, L. C.

arguments.claim: Imparting teaching was causa causans of the gift

anchor.surface_text: We have no doubt in this case that the imparting of the teaching was the causa causans of the making of the gift it was not merely a causa sine qua non.

arguments.claim: No exemption under s.4(3)(vii) as payments arose from exercise of vocation

anchor.surface_text: In the view that we take, namely, that the payments with which we are concerned, were income, arising from the vocation of the appellants a teacher of Vedanta, no question of exemption under s. 4(3)(vii) of the Act arises.

holdings.text: the teaching of Vedanta by the appellant in this case can properly be called the carrying on of a vocation by him

anchor.surface_text: We think therefore that the teaching of Vedanta by the appellant in this case can properly be called the carrying on of a vocation by him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Teaching generally is a vocation; Vedanta teaching same as any other; activity organised with regular disciples including Levy from England; single act or lack of system not bar; profit motive irrelevant; distinguished Stedeford v Beloe as pension not from current office

holdings.text: it is not the motive of the person doing an act which decides whether the act done by him is the carrying on of a business, profession or vocation. If any business, profession or vocation in fact produces an income, that is taxable income

anchor.surface_text: Again, it is well-established that it is not the motive of the person doing an act which decides whether the act done by him is the carrying on of a business, profession or vocation. If any business, profession or vocation in fact produces an income,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Well-established principle from Incorporated Council of Law Reporting (1888) followed consistently; income production determines taxability regardless of intent to profit

holdings.reasoning_summary: Imparting teaching was causa causans of payments; from donee's perspective, received by virtue of vocation; not personal gift per test in Reed v Seymour and Herbert v McQuade; distinguished mere affection as result of teaching; Blakiston v Cooper

holdings.text: in the case of a voluntary payment, no tax can be levied on it if it had been made for reasons purely personal to the donee and unconnected with his office or vocation while it will be taxable if it was made because of the office or vocation of the donee

anchor.surface_text: These cases illustrate the application of the well-settled principle that in the case of a voluntary payment, no tax can be levied on it if it had been made for reasons purely personal to the donee and unconnected with his office or vocation

holdings.reasoning_summary: Well-settled principle applied; test from recipient's standpoint whether accrues by virtue of office/vocation; donor motive irrelevant; quoted Collins MR in Herbert v McQuade and Rowlatt J in Reed v Seymour approved by Viscount Cave LC

holdings.reasoning_summary: Teaching caused esteem leading to gift; repeated payments aligned with visits for instruction; per Blakiston v Cooper, offerings to vicar as vicar taxable

holdings.text: no question of exemption under s. 4(3)(vii) of the Act arises

anchor.surface_text: no question of exemption under s. 4(3)(vii) of the Act arises. In order that a payment may be, exempted under that section, it has to be shown that it did

holdings.reasoning_summary: Payments arose from exercise of vocation, so no exemption applicable under section requiring non-arising from vocation

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Inland Revenue v. Incorporated Council of Law Reporting 1

anchor.surface_text: It was decided as early as 1888 in the case of the Commissioner of Inland Revenue v. Incorporated Council of Law Reporting 1  and followed ever since, that it is not essential to the carrying on of a trade that the people carrying it on should make a profit, nor is it even necessary to the carrying on of the trade that the people carrying it on should desire or wish to make a profit.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Inland Revenue v. Incorporated Council of Law Reporting
precedents.cited_proposition: it is not essential to the carrying on of a trade that the people carrying it on should make a profit, nor is it even necessary to the carrying on of the trade that the people carrying it on should desire or wish to make a profit

anchor.surface_text: The observation of Rowlatt, J., in Stedeford v. Beloe  2  to which we were referred by Mr. Sastri, that there could be no tax on pension granted to a retired headmaster as there is no background of business in it , was clearly not intended to lay down that without a profit motive there could be no business, profession or vocation.

precedents.cited_proposition: there could be no tax on pension granted to a retired headmaster as there is no background of business in it

precedents.citation: the same case in the House of Lords 1

anchor.surface_text: The pension could be taxed only if it had arisen out of the office and the only point decided was that it had not so arisen as the headmaster held no office, having retired earlier, at the date the pension had been granted see the same case in the House of Lords 1 .

precedents.cited_proposition: pension could be taxed only if arisen out of office held at the time

anchor.surface_text: So Collins M. R. in Herbert v. McQuade referring to Inland Revenue v. Strong said at p. 649 Now that judgment, whether or not the particular facts justified it, is certainly an affirmation of a principle of law that a payment may be liable to income-tax although it is voluntary on the part of the persons who made it,

precedents.cited_proposition: a payment may be liable to income-tax although voluntary, test is whether from standpoint of receiver it accrues by virtue of office

anchor.surface_text: Collins M. R. in Herbert v. McQuade referring to Inland Revenue v. Strong said at p. 649 Now that judgment, whether or not the particular facts justified it, is certainly an affirmation of a principle of law that a payment may be liable to income-tax although it is voluntary

precedents.cited_proposition: payment liable to tax though voluntary if accrues by virtue of office

anchor.surface_text: It is well established that in cases of this kind the real question is, as Rowlatt J. put it in Reed v. Seymour 1 , But is it in the nature of a personal gift or is it a remuneration?,

precedents.cited_proposition: is it in the nature of a personal gift or is it a remuneration?

anchor.surface_text: an observation which was quoted with approval by Viscount Cave, L. C. when the case went up to the House of Lords with the addition If the latter, it is subject to the tax if the former, it is not see Seymour Reed 2 .

precedents.cited_proposition: if remuneration, subject to tax; if personal gift, not

anchor.surface_text: An argument of this kind seems to have been advanced in Blakiston v. Cooper 3  and dealt with by Lord Ashbourne in the following words It was suggested that the offerings, were made as personal gifts to the Vicar as marks of esteem and respect.

precedents.cited_proposition: offerings given to the vicar as vicar form part of profits of office though marks of esteem
